answers.answer: Hi Bill; I remember you from days past. Your need to undergo treatment is clearly elective. At this point, things like work, family, insurance, and things like that should determine need.If you keep your snoot out of the Budweiser, you might never actually have to undergo treatment. What’s your doctor’s position on this? Your wife’s position? Do you feel you’re insurance will be available in say, 5 or 10 years? Hmm…Bill
Hey BillThanks for your input,I always appreciate others opinions,helps me make those TOUGH decisions a little easierThanks again

Hello,I have a slightly different viewpoint.  With little liver damage, like you, I delayed treatment for 4 years after I was diagnosed (had HCV for a total of 27 years).  I finally decided to treat (SOC + Alinia) because I felt lousy just about every day.Thankfully I cleared the virus this spring but the HCV took its toll over the years -- I developed latent autoimmune diabetes (LADA) from the HCV infection.  In LADA the overactivated immune system attacks the pancreas and destroys the insulin producing cells.  It's similar to type 1 diabetes and there's no cure.My point is it's not clear what damage the virus and accompanying immune response may inflict on other organs besides the liver.  That said, if I was considering treatment I'd watch the INFORM non-interferon trials closely.Bill1954 is right on when he says the decision to treat involves many factors because it is a life altering event for you and your family.  What I'm saying is there may be consequences in waiting too long.,Kittyface
Thanks for your response.  I am not familiar with the INFORM trials,or the (SOC+Alinia) treatment but I would like to look into it.
